questions.text: A 22 years male came to the casualty with a history of syncope. The pt had a family history of the sudden cardiac death of their brother at the age of 35. The ECG is shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Brugada syndrome. It is an autosomal dominant syndrome with a mutation in the scn5a gene. It is responsible for up to 50% of sudden death victims . It is characterized by ECG findings of rbbb and persistent st elevation in V1 –V3 , structurally normal heart and propensity for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias and J-point elevation. Patients are susceptible to ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation. Treatment of Brugada includes: Termination of ventricular arrhythmia. Intracardiac defibrillator is the first line of treatment. Quinidine can be used in treatment. In this case, there is a history of sudden death in relatives with ecg patterns suggestive of Brugada syndrome.

questions.text: A 55 years old male with a complaint of breathlessness came to the casualty with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy. The ECG is shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left anterior fascicular block Fascicular blocks occur due to anatomical or functional blocks in a fascicle. Block in the anterior fascicle causes left anterior fascicular block (lafb) and block in the posterior fascicle causes posterior fascicular block (lpfb). Ecg criteria for left anterior fascicular block are: Electrical axis between -45 degrees to -90 degrees . QRS duration < 0. 12 seconds but slightly prolonged. Avl shows qr complex. V5-v6 usually also shows qr complexes. Lead 2, 3, avf display rs complexes. Henceforth, its left anterior fascicular block.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B . Left posterior fascicular block: Electrical axis between +90 degrees to +180 degrees. Rs complexes in lead 1 and avl. Qr complexes in inferior leads (2, 3, avf). Qrs duration < 0. 12 seconds Q-wave is mandatory in leads 3 and avf. In the above-given ecg all the above features are absent, hence, it's not a left posterior fascicular block.

questions.text: A 55 years male came to the casualty with known history of diabetes and hypertension for the last 5 years. Presently he is asymptomatic. His ecg is shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mobitz type 1 [wenckebach phenomenon] Ecg features : Progressive prolongation of pr interval. Pr interval is longest immediately before dropped beat. Pr interval is shortest immediately after a dropped beat. The rr interval progressively shortens with each beat. Henceforth, its mobitz type 1 block.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. it's not a left anterior fascicular block. Option: C. it's not a left posterior fascicular block.
